item.title: Biden announces U.S. will airdrop food aid into Gaza as famine concerns grow
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Shabad and Allie Raffa and Ghael Fobes and Tara Prindiville and Megan Lebowitz
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden announced Friday that the U.S. will drop food aid into the Gaza Strip, noting that the humanitarian aid flowing into the region for Palestinians is insufficient.

media:content.media:text: Displaced Palestinian children gather to receive food at a government school in Rafah, Gaza
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinian children gather to receive food at a government school in Rafah, Gaza on Feb. 19, 2024.

item.title: Thousands turn out to mourn Navalny, defying Putin, at funeral in Moscow
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith
item.description: Alexei Navalny's funeral on Friday brought out thousands who braved the snow, heavy security and weeks of Kremlin efforts to derail the event so that they could pay their respects the opposition leader.

media:content.media:text: Funeral of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny
media:content.media:description: Mourners attend a funeral service for Russian opposition politician Alexei Navalny at the Soothe My Sorrows church in Moscow on March 1, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Relatives and supporters of Alexei Navalny are bidding farewell to the opposition leader at a funeral in southeastern Moscow, following a battle with authorities over the release of his body after his still-unexplained death in an Arctic penal colony.
media:content.media:description: People gather outside the church during Navalny's funeral.

media:content.media:text: Funeral of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny
media:content.media:description: Mourners line the streets near the Borisovskoye Cemetery, as official vehicles appeared to block the highway outside.

media:content.media:text: Funeral of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny
media:content.media:description: Navalny's body is displayed in an open casket during his funeral at the Soothe My Sorrows church in Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Mexico City's 21 million residents are facing a severe water shortage
item.dc:creator: Denise Chow and Albinson Linares
item.description: Mexico City is in the grips of a severe water crisis, as lingering drought and years of low rainfall push the city's already-strained water system to the limit.

media:content.media:text: A woman walks near a water tanker truck in Mexico City.
media:content.media:description: A woman walks near a water tanker truck in Mexico City in January.

media:content.media:text: People fill buckets with water from a water tanker truck in the Azcapotzalco neighborhood in Mexico City on Jan. 26, 2024.
media:content.media:description: People fill buckets with water from a tanker truck in Mexico City on Jan. 26.

item.title: Families of U.S. hostages in Gaza set to attend State of the Union
item.dc:creator: Ryan Nobles and Monica Alba and Garrett Haake
item.description: Family members plan to ask lawmakers and their staffers to wear yellow ribbons and dog tags to the speech in a sign of solidarity.

media:content.media:text: Jonathan Dekel-Chen, father of Sagui Dekel-Chen speaks at the White House
media:content.media:description: Jonathan Dekel-Chen, father of Sagui Dekel-Chen, speaks at the White House in 2023.

item.title: New Black Muslim group wants to put pressure on Biden — but not abandon him
item.dc:creator: Yamiche Alcindor
item.description: A new national organization called the Black Muslim Leadership Council is hoping to pressure elected officials, including President Joe Biden, to call for a permanent ceasefire in the Middle East.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden speaks
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden during the 2024 House Democratic Issues Conference in Leesburg, Va., on Feb. 8.

item.title: More than 100 killed as Israeli troops accused of opening fire on Gazans crowded around aid convoy
item.dc:creator: Raf Sanchez
item.description: Israeli forces opened fire on a crowd of Palestinians hoping to get food from aid trucks in Gaza. At least 112 people were killed and more than 769 injured.

media:content.media:text: Image: The body of a Palestinian killed in an early morning incident
media:content.media:description: The body of a Palestinian killed in an early morning incident when residents rushed toward aid trucks in Gaza City on Feb. 29, 2024.

media:content.media:text: The body of a Palestinian killed when Israeli forces opened fire on crowds rushing at an aid distribution point in Gaza City.
media:content.media:description: More than 100 people were killed and over 700 injured in an overnight attack on a crowd of Palestinians rushing an aid convoy.

media:content.media:text: Image: A woman sits among Palestinians at Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City
media:content.media:description: A woman sits among the injured at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City. Hundreds were injured in the attack, including by stampeding crowds or run over by aid trucks.

media:content.media:text: Image: People mourn at Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City
media:content.media:description: Mourners at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Thursday.

item.title: Biden still 'hopeful' but walks back prediction of Monday cease-fire deal in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Shabad and Monica Alba and Megan Lebowitz and Henry Austin
item.description: President Joe Biden expressed skepticism a ceasefire could be struck in the Israel-Hamas war by Monday, as he had said he hoped would happen.

media:content.media:text: Joe Biden at the White House
media:content.media:description: Joe Biden at the White House on Feb. 28, 2024.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Europe tries to Trump-proof itself as Putin's war in Ukraine looms over NATO
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and Andy Eckardt
item.description: November’s presidential election may be nine months away, but Europe is already trying to Trump-proof itself, officials on the continent have told NBC News.

media:content.media:text: Many believe that Trump would be economically protectionist and perhaps even launch new trade wars against Europe.
media:content.media:description: Many believe that Trump would be economically protectionist and perhaps even launch new trade wars against Europe.

media:content.media:text: Many believe that Trump would be economically protectionist and perhaps even launch new trade wars against Europe.
media:content.media:description: Many believe that Donald Trump would be economically protectionist and perhaps even launch new trade wars against Europe.

media:content.media:text: Trump NATO Summit
media:content.media:description: Then-President Donald Trump shaking hands with Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg at the NATO summit in London on Dec. 4, 2019.

item.title: King Charles' cancer diagnosis was a rare royal health revelation but still left much unsaid
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith
item.description: Britain’s King George VI died 72 years ago Tuesday after cancer treatment so secret that it was hidden from the media, the public — and perhaps even the king himself.

media:content.media:text: King Charles III Leaves Hospital After Receiving Treatment For An Enlarged Prostate
media:content.media:description: King Charles III departs with Queen Camilla after receiving treatment for an enlarged prostate at The London Clinic on Jan. 29, 2024.

media:content.media:text: King Charles London Clinic
media:content.media:description: King Charles stayed at the London Clinic following prostate surgery.

media:content.media:text: Buckingham Palace announced Monday evening that the king has begun outpatient treatment for an undisclosed form of cancer.
media:content.media:description: Artists created paintings wishing Britain's King Charles III a speedy recovery in Mumbai, India, on Tuesday.

item.title: Is Kim Jong Un preparing North Korea for war?
item.dc:creator: Stella Kim and Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un may be taking the Korean Peninsula closer to armed conflict, analysts have warned, amid intensifying nuclear threats and tests.

media:content.media:text: Is Kim Jong Un Preparing For War?
media:content.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has analysts increasingly worried about his intentions.

media:content.media:text: north korea satellite launch
media:content.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un watching the launch of a rocket carrying a reconnaissance satellite in November.

media:content.media:text: Kim Putin Meeting Russia
media:content.media:description: Kim with Russian President Vladimir Putin during their meeting at a Russian spaceport in September.

media:content.media:text: North Korea fired a mid-range ballistic missile on October 4, which flew over Japan, Seoul and Tokyo said, a significant escalation as Pyongyang ramps up its record-breaking weapons-testing blitz.
media:content.media:description: United Nations Command and South Korean soldiers patrolling the Demilitarized Zone in the truce village of Panmunjom in 2022.

item.title: Funeral for Alexei Navalny draws thousands of Russians
item.description: The late Russian opposition leader lay in an open casket during a short funeral service, as thousands of Navalny's supporters watched the service and Navalny's burial. NBC News' Keir Simmons reports.

media:content.media:title: Funeral for Alexei Navalny draws thousands of Russians
media:content.media:description: The late Russian opposition leader lay in an open casket during a short funeral service, as thousands of Navalny's supporters watched the service and Navalny's burial. NBC News' Keir Simmons reports.

item.title: Biden administration announces U.S. aid drops into Gaza
item.description: The U.S. is planning to launch air drops of food to Gaza as the humanitarian crisis worsens after almost five months of war between Israel and Hamas. NBC News' Peter Alexander reports.

media:content.media:title: Biden administration announces U.S. aid drops into Gaza
media:content.media:description: The U.S. is planning to launch air drops of food to Gaza as the humanitarian crisis worsens after almost five months of war between Israel and Hamas. NBC News' Peter Alexander reports.

item.title: Gazan doctor says bullets and shells caused aid truck casualties
item.description: Speaking to NBC News at Gaza City’s Al-Shifa Hospital, Dr. Mohmmed Mahmoud Eghrad said, “Perhaps a small number of [injuries] were due to trampling and pushing, but the trampling itself happened because of the shooting that came from the Israeli occupation forces.”

media:content.media:title: Gazan doctor says bullets and shells caused aid truck casualties
media:content.media:description: Speaking to NBC News at Gaza City’s Al-Shifa Hospital, Dr. Mohmmed Mahmoud Eghrad said, “Perhaps a small number of [injuries] were due to trampling and pushing, but the trampling itself happened because of the shooting that came from the Israeli occupation forces.”

item.title: Thousands attend Alexei Navalny funeral as Russian police monitor closely
item.description: A funeral service was held in Moscow for Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, which was closely monitored by Russian police. NBC News' Matt Bodner reports on the details of the funeral where thousands of supporters showed up in solidarity with Navalny.

media:content.media:title: Thousands attend Alexei Navalny funeral as Russian police monitor closely
media:content.media:description: A funeral service was held in Moscow for Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, which was closely monitored by Russian police. NBC News' Matt Bodner reports on the details of the funeral where thousands of supporters showed up in solidarity with Navalny.

item.title: ‘Banker to the poor’ Muhammad Yunus threatened with prison in Bangladesh
item.description: Nobel peace laureate Muhammad Yunus talks to NBC News about the legal charges he is facing in his home country of Bangladesh, despite the fact that “the whole world is celebrating me for helping the poor people get out of poverty.”

media:content.media:title: ‘Banker to the poor’ Muhammad Yunus threatened with prison in Bangladesh
media:content.media:description: Nobel peace laureate Muhammad Yunus talks to NBC News about the legal charges he is facing in his home country of Bangladesh, despite the fact that “the whole world is celebrating me for helping the poor people get out of poverty.”

item.title: Ghana's anti-LGBTQ bill draws international condemnation after it is passed by parliament
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A bill which criminalizes LGBTQ people in Ghana and their supporters drew international condemnation after it was passed by parliament, with the U.N. calling it “profoundly disturbing."

media:content.media:text: Protesters carry signs in Harlem.
media:content.media:description: Protesters at a 2021 rally in New York City against a bill proposed in Ghana's parliament that would make identifying as LGBTQ or an ally a criminal offense

item.title: Australian officials reprimand Meta after tech giant says it will stop paying for news
item.dc:creator: Daniel Arkin
item.description: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, announced that it plans to stop striking deals to pay publishers of news content in Australia.

media:content.media:text: A sign of the Meta logo at the company's headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.
media:content.media:description: A sign with the Meta logo at the company's headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif.

item.title: Pakistan swears in new parliament as Imran Khan's followers protest vote count
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Pakistan swore in a new parliament on Thursday in a chaotic scene as allies of former Prime Minister Imran Khan protested what they claim was a rigged election.

media:content.media:text: Pakistan's National Assembly swore in newly elected members on Thursday in a chaotic scene, as allies of jailed former Premier Khan protested what they claim was a rigged election.
media:content.media:description: Newly elected lawmakers in Pakistan displayed posters of jailed former Prime Minister Imran Khan at the opening session of the parliament in Islamabad on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: Pakistan's National Assembly swore in newly elected members on Thursday in a chaotic scene, as allies of jailed former Premier Khan protested what they claim was a rigged election.
media:content.media:description: Omar Ayub, right, a lawmaker backed by Khan, is the only candidate for prime minister in this Sunday’s vote aside from former premier Shehbaz Sharif.

item.title: India's richest man is bringing Rihanna and 1,200 guests to a pre-wedding bash for his son
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Indian industrialist Mukesh Ambani is expecting billionaires, heads of state and Hollywood and Bollywood royalty at a pre-wedding bash for his son this weekend.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Anant Ambani and his fiancée, Radhika Merchant, during pre-wedding celebrations near Jamnagar, India, on Wednesday.

media:content.media:text: India Wedding Zuckerberg
media:content.media:description: Meta chief Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, in Jamnagar on Thursday.

item.title: India 'easily' the fastest-growing economy, IMF executive director says, as GDP growth blows past estimates
item.dc:creator: Shreyashi Sanyal, CNBC
item.description: India is “easily” the fastest-growing economy in the world, the IMF’s executive director said, as the country’s third-quarter GDP growth blew past estimates.

media:content.media:text: Mumbai Finds an Underground Solution to Its Above-Ground Chaos
media:content.media:description: A construction site in Mumbai, India, last year.

item.title: Mall fire in Bangladesh capital kills at least 43
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A fire at a six-story shopping mall in the capital of Bangladesh killed at least 43 people overnight and injured dozens of others, the health minister said.

media:content.media:text: fire emergency firefighters
media:content.media:description: Firefighters working to contain a fire at a shopping mall in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: fire emergency water hose
media:content.media:description: More than a dozen firefighting units were deployed to douse the fire at the Green Cozy Cottage Shopping Mall.

item.title: World Cup winner Paul Pogba banned 4 years for doping
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Once one of the world’s top midfielders, Paul Pogba was banned for the maximum four years by Italy’s anti-doping court on Thursday after the World Cup winner tested positive for testosterone while at Juventus.

media:content.media:text: Paul Pogba of Juventus
media:content.media:description: Paul Pogba of Juventus during an Italian league match between Juventus and Bologna at Allianz Stadium in Turin on Aug. 27.

item.title: Canada reimposes visa requirement on Mexican nationals
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Canada’s government is reimposing visa requirements on Mexican nationals visiting Canada after asylum claims, most of which are rejected, have spiked dramatically.

media:content.media:text: Image: Justin Trudeau
media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at a news conference in Vancouver on Feb. 20.

item.title: As Gaza death toll tops 30,000, is Israel on the path to victory or quagmire?
item.dc:creator: Dan De Luce and Yasmine Salam and Raf Sanchez and Anna Schecter and Courtney Kube and Chantal Da Silva
item.description: As the death toll in Gaza tops 30,000 and international criticism mounts, Israeli forces believe they are on the path to victory against Hamas. Are they?

media:content.media:text: An Israeli soldier at the border with the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: An Israeli soldier at the border with the Gaza Strip on Feb. 21.

media:content.media:text: The body of a Palestinian killed when Israeli forces opened fire on crowds rushing at an aid distribution point in Gaza City.
media:content.media:description: The body of a Palestinian killed when Israeli forces opened fire on crowds rushing at an aid distribution point in Gaza City on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: People mourn in Gaza City
media:content.media:description: People mourn in Gaza City on Thursday.
